name: Fruit
description:
Fruit is a [dependency injection](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dependency_injection) framework for C++, loosely inspired by the Guice framework for Java. It uses C++ metaprogramming together with some new C++11 features to detect most injection problems at compile-time.
It allows to split the implementation code in "components" (aka modules) that can be assembled to form other components.
From a component with no requirements it's then possible to create an injector, that provides an instance of the interfaces exposed by the component.

See the [wiki](https://github.com/google/fruit/wiki) for more information, including installation instructions, tutorials and reference documentation.
description_good_justification:
Short description at: <https://github.com/google/fruit>
Longer description at: <https://github.com/google/fruit/wiki>

repo_public_justification: Repository on GitHub, which provides public git repositories with URLs.
repo_track_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git can track the changes, who made them, and when they were made.
repo_interim_justification: All development is in the open. See <https://github.com/google/fruit/commits/master>.
repo_distributed_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git is distributed.
version_unique_justification: Each release has a version in the X.Y.Z format. See <https://github.com/google/fruit/releases>.
version_tags_justification: There's a git tag "vX.Y.Z" for each release "X.Y.Z".
release_notes_justification: Each release comes with manually curated release notes. See <https://github.com/google/fruit/releases>.
release_notes_vulns_justification: There were no known vulnerabilities so far (public or otherwise).
report_responses_justification: Issues are usually replied to within a few days.
enhancement_responses_justification: Issues are usually replied to within a few days.
report_archive_justification: The issue tracker at <https://github.com/google/fruit/issues> allows to search for past and current issues and the respective responses.
vulnerability_report_private_justificati: Private vulnerability reports are not supported.
vulnerability_report_response_justificat: Private vulnerability reports are not supported.
build_justification: Fruit supports two (independent) build systems: CMake and Bazel.
build_floss_tools_justification: For example, Fruit can be built on Linux using GCC + GNU Make + CMake.
test_invocation_justification:
When Fruit is built using CMake, ctest can be used to run the tests.
When Fruit is built using Bazel, Bazel can be used to run the tests.
test_most_justification: As of Fruit 3.1.0, Fruit's test suite has 96.6% (line) coverage.
test_policy_justification: All new functionality comes with tests (typically end-to-end, python-based tests).
tests_documented_added_justification:
The pull request documentation here:
https://github.com/google/fruit/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#sending-pull-requests
Specifies that tests should be added where relevant.
warnings_justification: "-W -Wall" is used when building in debug mode (including for CI testing), and similar flags are used for Visual Studio.
warnings_fixed_justification: "-Werror" is used to ensure that build warnings are treated as if they were build errors. A similar flag is used for Visual Studio.
warnings_strict_justification: "-W -Wall" is used when building in debug mode (including for CI testing), and similar flags are used for Visual Studio.
crypto_published_justification: No cryptographic protocols and algorithms are used.
crypto_call_justification: No cryptographic protocols and algorithms are used.
crypto_floss_justification: No cryptographic protocols and algorithms are used.
crypto_keylength_justification: This project doesn't use cryptographic keys (nor any other cryptographic facilities).
crypto_working_justification: This project doesn't use any cryptographic algorithms.
crypto_pfs_justification: This project doesn't use any cryptographic algorithms.
crypto_password_storage_justification: This project doesn't involve any authentication credentials.
crypto_random_justification: This project doesn't use any cryptographic algorithms.
delivery_mitm_justification: This project doesn't involve any form of network communication.
delivery_unsigned_justification: This project doesn't involve any form of network communication.
vulnerabilities_fixed_60_days_justificat: No vulnerabilities are known, nor were reported.
vulnerabilities_critical_fixed_justifica: No vulnerabilities are known, nor were reported.
static_analysis_justification: Fruit uses Coverity for static analysis.
static_analysis_often_justification:
Due to the commit frequency, running static analysis for each commit or daily would be overkill.
Also, Coverity advises against per-commit static analysis (for the same reason).
dynamic_analysis_justification: Fruit uses GCC and clang's dynamic analyzers (ASan, UBSan), they run for each git push.
dynamic_analysis_unsafe_justification: Address Sanitizer, Undefined Behavior Sanitizer and valgrind are used in CI (so they run for every commit).
dynamic_analysis_enable_assertions_justi: There are many debug-only assertions that can be enabled using the FRUIT_DEBUG and FRUIT_EXTRA_DEBUG macros. These assertions are checked when running CI tests in debug mode (so they're checked for every commit).
dynamic_analysis_fixed_justification: No such vulnerabilities have ever been found. If any will be found, they will be fixed in a timely manner.
crypto_weaknesses_justification: This project doesn't use any cryptographic algorithms.
test_continuous_integration_justificatio: Fruit is set up for continuous integration using Travis CI (for Linux and OS X) and Appveyor (for Windows).
discussion_justification: GitHub supports discussions on issues and pull requests.
no_leaked_credentials_justification: The repositories don't contain any private credentials.
english_justification: The documentation (<https://github.com/google/fruit/wiki>) is in English, and English is also used in the issue tracker (<https://github.com/google/fruit/issues>).
hardened_site_justification: Found all required security hardening headers.

name: View Admin As
description: View the WordPress admin as a different role, switch between users, temporarily change your capabilities, set default screen settings for roles, manage your roles and capabilities.
description_good_justification:
This plugin will add a menu item to your admin bar where you can change your view in the WordPress admin without the need to login with a user that has this role!

If you've selected a user, you can also change this user's preferences; like screen settings on various admin pages. You can also switch to a role or temporarily change your own capabilities.

With the "Role defaults" module you can set default screen settings for roles and apply them on users through various bulk actions.

It also features a "Role manager" module to add, edit or remove roles and grant or deny them capabilities.

general_comments:
I‚Äôve created this at first for myself since I‚Äôm a developer and often need to see the outcome on roles which my clients use.

So, when you are developing a plugin or theme that does anything with roles or capabilities you can use this plugin to easily check if everything works. No more hassle of creating test users and constantly logging out and in anymore!

This plugin is also useful to support your clients and/or users. For example; make screen display presets of the edit and overview pages before you let them log in.

name: cJSON
description: Ultralightweight JSON parser in ANSI C
contribution_justification: Projects on GitHub by default use issues and pull requests, as encouraged by documentation such as <https://guides.github.com/activities/contributing-to-open-source/>.
license_location_justification: Non-trivial license location file in repository: <https://github.com/DaveGamble/cJSON/blob/master/LICENSE>.
floss_license_justification: The MIT license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
floss_license_osi_justification: The MIT license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
documentation_basics_justification: There is documentation in the README, but it could be better.
documentation_interface_justification:
The external interface is documented in the library header.
https://github.com/DaveGamble/cJSON/blob/master/cJSON.h
repo_public_justification: Repository on GitHub, which provides public git repositories with URLs.
repo_track_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git can track the changes, who made them, and when they were made.
repo_interim_justification: Every single commit contained in releases is public. Some (but not all) changes are merged via github pull requests instead of directly pushing to the repository.
repo_distributed_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git is distributed.
release_notes_justification: Non-trivial release notes file in repository: <https://github.com/DaveGamble/cJSON/blob/master/CHANGELOG.md>.
enhancement_responses_justification: At time of writing there is no GitHub issue that has not been at least responded to.
test_invocation_justification: There is no standard way for unit testing in C, but testing is done using CMake's CTest, which produces standard test targets for most CMake backends.
test_most_justification: The tests cover most of cJSON but it is still lacking full coverage especially for small utility functions.
warnings_justification:
The CMake build file contains an extensive list of compiler warnings.
https://github.com/DaveGamble/cJSON/blob/master/CMakeLists.txt
warnings_fixed_justification: -Werror is enabled for GCC and Clang, so all warnings have to be addressed for cJSON to build. The only exceptions are the unit tests, where some compiler flags have been disabled, but generally warnings are fixed there as well.
warnings_strict_justification:
Almost all warnings that Clang and GCC provide are enabled and -Werror ensures that they are enforced.
-Werror is enforced in release builds as well, so users provide bug reports if there are warnings.
delivery_mitm_justification: The main delivery method of cJSON is via GitHub, which provides access via HTTPS.
delivery_unsigned_justification: No cryptographic hashes are provided other than the git commit ids (which use the compromised SHA1 algorithm). GitHub and HTTPS is relied upon for integrity, publishing hashes would not help in this case. It would only help to detect transmission errors.
static_analysis_justification: Clang static analyzer is used. Also Coverity https://scan.coverity.com/projects/cjson?tab=overview although coverity is not used consistently for every single release.
static_analysis_often_justification: Static analysis is performed every once in a while, but definitely before every release.
dynamic_analysis_justification: AddressSanitizer, UndefinedBehaviorSanitizer and Valgrind are used on every commit.
dynamic_analysis_unsafe_justification:
AddressSanitizer, UndefinedBehaviorSanitizer and Valgrind are used on every commit.
Every once in a while fuzzing is done via AFL.
dynamic_analysis_enable_assertions_justi: There is no use of 'assert' but error conditions (such as invalid input, out of memory etc.) are handled at runtime.
test_continuous_integration_justificatio:
https://travis-ci.org/FSMaxB/cJSON
Travis-CI actually runs on FSMaxB/cJSON since I as a maintainer don't have full access to DaveGamble/cJSON. But FSMaxB/cJSON is kept in sync with the main repository.
Additionally there is a private Jenkins instance that tests the code on different processor architectures.
discussion_justification: GitHub supports discussions on issues and pull requests.
hardening_justification: Currently cJSON sets '-fstack-protector-strong' for GCC and Clang. More will be investigated in the future.
hardened_site_justification: Found all required security hardening headers.
installation_common_justification: cJSON's CMake build system definition file provides a target for installing the library, it's headers and pkgconfig files.

name: eID Middleware repository
description: Official software for the Belgian electronic identity card
contribution_justification: Projects on GitHub by default use issues and pull requests, as encouraged by documentation such as <https://guides.github.com/activities/contributing-to-open-source/>.
contribution_requirements_justification: There are no such formal requirements
license_location_justification: Non-trivial license location file in repository: <https://github.com/Fedict/eid-mw/blob/master/COPYING>.
floss_license_justification: The LGPL-3.0 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
floss_license_osi_justification: The LGPL-3.0 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
documentation_basics_justification: documentation is found in the /doc directory of the repository, on the project's wiki, and on its official website
repo_public_justification: Repository on GitHub, which provides public git repositories with URLs.
repo_track_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git can track the changes, who made them, and when they were made.
repo_distributed_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git is distributed.
version_tags_justification: We tag every release in git, usually signed tags -- unless we forget, which sometimes happens
release_notes_justification: Release notes are provided through the official distribution channels on https://eid.belgium.be/
report_process_justification: Can be done through the standard github issue trackers on https://github.com/Fedict/eid-mw/issues
report_archive_justification:
issues are recorded in github -- https://github.com/Fedict/eid-mw/issues

Additionally, a google group exists, where sometimes issues are reported, too: https://groups.google.com/forum/#!forum/eid-middleware-dev
vulnerability_report_process_justificati: Just uses GitHub, people can use the GitHub issue tracking system at https://github.com/Fedict/eid-mw/issue
vulnerability_report_private_justificati: private reports are not currently supported
vulnerability_report_response_justificat: no vulnerability report has been received in at least the past three years
build_floss_tools_justification: The project is buildable using only FLOSS tools on FLOSS platforms. For the Windows and OSX platform, native tools are required (i.e., Xcode and Visual Studio) to build the software.
test_justification: Test suite exists and is part of the standard build systems
test_most_justification: It's not okay, but full coverage is difficult
test_policy_justification:
Software is in maintenance-only mode, no major new functionality is expected.

Additionally, when the environments on which the software runs change drastically, updating the software so it can be used against in the minimal possible amount of time is way more important than ensuring test suite completeness
tests_are_added_justification: Since there is no such policy, it is met...
warnings_fixed_justification: Code currently compiles warning-free, apart from deprecation warnings for constructs that we need to retain for backward compatibility
crypto_published_justification: The software allows the use of SHA1, but only for backwards compatibility.
crypto_call_justification: The major goal of this software is to allow access to the card to perform, e.g., cryptographic operations. It does not implement these operations itself, although it does implement a few cryptographically secure hashing algorithms.
crypto_keylength_justification: Key lengths are configured on the card, not using the software. Some older cards use 1024-bit RSA keys, and dropping support for this is not an option.
crypto_pfs_justification: software implements access to a card for RSA and hashing, does not implement a full TLS stack, and PFS does not apply
crypto_password_storage_justification: software implements access to a card for RSA and hashing, does not store any passwords
crypto_random_justification: keys are not generated by this software
delivery_mitm_justification: software is shipped on https://eid.belgium.be/, and Linux binaries through signed repositories
delivery_unsigned_justification: no hashes are provided through eid.belgium.be, hashes in repositories are cryptographically signed
vulnerabilities_fixed_60_days_justificat: no vulnerabilities in the past three years, at least
static_analysis_justification: Coverity Scan on an automated weekly basis; occasionally the clang static analyzer too
static_analysis_common_vulnerabilities_j: Coverity Scan does have such rules
static_analysis_often_justification: project has too many LOC for daily checks with coverity, but it is done weekly.
crypto_weaknesses_justification: We must allow SHA1 for backwards compatibility with older cards
test_continuous_integration_justificatio: we use both travis and buildbot to do this. The test suite is run as part of both.
discussion_justification: GitHub supports discussions on issues and pull requests.
hardened_site_justification: Found all required security hardening headers. X-Content-Type-Options was not set to "nosniff". One or more of the required security hardening headers is missing.
installation_common_justification: installers for Windows and macOS, package repositories for well-known Linux distributions, source tarball for other systems

name: Hyperledger Composer
description: Hyperledger Composer is a framework for building Blockchain business networks
description_good_justification:
A succinct description is provided on the home page, via the three main points:
https://hyperledger.github.io/composer/

A more complete description is provided as the introduction in the documentation:
https://hyperledger.github.io/composer/introduction/introduction.html
interact_justification:
Installation guides available in the documentation:
https://hyperledger.github.io/composer/installing/installing-index.html

Support page describes how to provide feedback and contribute:
https://hyperledger.github.io/composer/support/support-index.html
contribution_justification:
Contributing guide explains the contribution process using pull requests:
https://github.com/hyperledger/composer/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md
license_location_justification:
Project is licensed under the Apache-2.0 license:
https://github.com/hyperledger/composer/blob/master/LICENSE.txt
floss_license_justification:
Project is licensed under the Apache-2.0 license:
https://github.com/hyperledger/composer/blob/master/LICENSE.txt

Documentation shows this as well (scroll to bottom):
https://hyperledger.github.io/composer/ The Apache-2.0 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
floss_license_osi_justification: Apache-2.0 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI). The Apache-2.0 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
documentation_basics_justification:
Project documentation provided here:
https://hyperledger.github.io/composer/
documentation_interface_justification:
Project documentation provided here:
https://hyperledger.github.io/composer/

For example, details of APIs provided by the project:
https://hyperledger.github.io/composer/applications/node.html
https://hyperledger.github.io/composer/integrating/getting-started-rest-api.html
repo_public_justification:
Repository on GitHub, which provides public git repositories with URLs:
https://github.com/hyperledger/composer
repo_track_justification:
Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git can track the changes, who made them, and when they were made:
https://github.com/hyperledger/composer Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git can track the changes, who made them, and when they were made.
repo_interim_justification:
Full tracking of source code, including interim versions in-between weekly releases, is tracked on GitHub in the master branch:
https://github.com/hyperledger/composer

GitHub releases are used for cutting weekly releases from the master branch.
repo_distributed_justification:
Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git is distributed:
https://github.com/hyperledger/composer Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git is distributed.
version_unique_justification:
Weekly releases are created using unique version numbers:
https://github.com/hyperledger/composer/releases
version_tags_justification:
GitHub releases and tags track each weekly release:
https://github.com/hyperledger/composer/releases
https://github.com/hyperledger/composer/tags
release_notes_justification:
Each weekly release includes release notes, lovingly written by the team, for example:
https://github.com/hyperledger/composer/releases/tag/v0.16.0
release_notes_vulns_justification:
There have been no publicly known vulnerabilities.
However, bugs fixed in each release are recorded in the release notes:
https://github.com/hyperledger/composer/releases/tag/v0.16.0
report_tracker_justification:
Issues are individually tracked as GitHub issues, for example:
https://github.com/hyperledger/composer/issues/2799
report_process_justification:
Bug reports are raised as issues on GitHub, and we provide a template to collect required information:
https://github.com/hyperledger/composer/issues/new

Everybody has permission to create an issue on GitHub.
report_responses_justification: We go through a regular process of reviewing and tagging all new bug reports.
enhancement_responses_justification: We go through a regular process of reviewing and tagging all new enhancement requests.
build_justification:
Travis CI is used to automatically build pull requests, merge builds, and release builds:
https://travis-ci.org/hyperledger/composer
build_common_tools_justification: Standard open source build tools for JavaScript software are used for building the software, including Node.js and npm.
build_floss_tools_justification: Standard open source build tools for JavaScript software are used for building the software, including Node.js and npm.
test_justification: The project includes automated unit tests, functional tests, and integration tests of all software components.
test_invocation_justification:
All unit tests are automated using "npm test", which is the standard way for JavaScript.
Additional npm targets have been set up to run the functional tests and integration tests.
test_most_justification: We use Istanbul, a code coverage tool, to try and ensure that the unit tests cover 100% of the code. We currently have some minor debt to clean up where we are not quite at 100%, but we are very close.
test_policy_justification:
Code cannot be merged without adding unit tests that cover 100% of the code. The pull request build will fail and the maintainers cannot merge a failed build.
We encourage contributors to deliver functional and integration tests at the same time as the code, but often this is delivered in a follow up pull request.
tests_are_added_justification:
The builds and automated tests are run for each release build of the project.
These can be viewed in Travis CI.
See this pull request for an example which adds unit tests and functional tests to verify the move from ES5 to ES7 for transaction processor functions:
https://github.com/hyperledger/composer/pull/2925/files
tests_documented_added_justification:
Requirements for testing are documented in the contributing guide:
https://github.com/hyperledger/composer/blob/master/contrib-notes/coding-guidelines.md#testing
warnings_justification:
The JavaScript linting tool eslint is used to scan all JavaScript code:
https://github.com/hyperledger/composer/blob/master/packages/composer-client/.eslintrc.yml

The TypeScript linting tool tslint is used to scan all TypeScript code:
https://github.com/hyperledger/composer/blob/master/packages/composer-playground/tslint.json
warnings_fixed_justification: Linting checks cause the build to fail. Code that fails to pass the linting checks will cause the pull request build to fail, and maintainers will be unable to merge the changes.
warnings_strict_justification: We turn on a lot of linting rules, based upon the set of rules recommended by the linting tools.
crypto_published_justification: All cryptography used by Hyperledger Composer is provided by the underlying blockchain technology, currently Hyperledger Fabric.
crypto_call_justification: All cryptography used by Hyperledger Composer is provided by the underlying blockchain technology, currently Hyperledger Fabric.
crypto_floss_justification: All cryptography used by Hyperledger Composer is provided by the underlying blockchain technology, currently Hyperledger Fabric.
crypto_keylength_justification: All cryptography used by Hyperledger Composer is provided by the underlying blockchain technology, currently Hyperledger Fabric.
crypto_working_justification: All cryptography used by Hyperledger Composer is provided by the underlying blockchain technology, currently Hyperledger Fabric.
crypto_pfs_justification: All cryptography used by Hyperledger Composer is provided by the underlying blockchain technology, currently Hyperledger Fabric.
crypto_password_storage_justification: All cryptography used by Hyperledger Composer is provided by the underlying blockchain technology, currently Hyperledger Fabric.
crypto_random_justification: All cryptography used by Hyperledger Composer is provided by the underlying blockchain technology, currently Hyperledger Fabric.
delivery_mitm_justification: Software is delivered via standard mechanisms, either npm or Docker Hub. Both are secured using https.
delivery_unsigned_justification: Software is delivered via standard mechanisms, either npm or Docker Hub. Both are secured using https.
vulnerabilities_fixed_60_days_justificat: There are no currently open vulnerabilities of medium or high severity.
dynamic_analysis_justification: release criteria require dynamic scan(s) be completed prior to release
crypto_weaknesses_justification: All cryptography used by Hyperledger Composer is provided by the underlying blockchain technology, currently Hyperledger Fabric.
test_continuous_integration_justificatio:
All pull requests are automatically built and tested, as are merge builds, and release builds.
Code cannot be integrated into the main repository without going through a build and test cycle.
discussion_justification: GitHub supports discussions on issues and pull requests.
no_leaked_credentials_justification:
The public repository only contains sample credentials used in testing, such as the default ID/secret for the Fabric CA.
Travis CI secrets are used to protect API keys that are used for publishing to npm, Docker Hub, and Bluemix.
english_justification:
Project documentation provided in English here:
https://hyperledger.github.io/composer/

GitHub issue tracker allows anybody to raise bug reports/comments in English:
https://github.com/hyperledger/composer/issues
hardened_site_justification: X-Content-Type-Options was not set to "nosniff". # X-Content-Type-Options was not set to "nosniff". // X-Content-Type-Options was not set to "nosniff".

name: LDAPImporter
description: Simple script to read from a CSV file and import rows into an LDAP database.
contribution_justification: Projects on GitHub by default use issues and pull requests, as encouraged by documentation such as <https://guides.github.com/activities/contributing-to-open-source/>.
license_location_justification: Non-trivial license location file in repository: <https://github.com/QNimbus/LDAPImporter/blob/master/LICENSE.md>.
floss_license_justification: The MIT license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
floss_license_osi_justification: The MIT license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
documentation_basics_justification: No appropriate folder found for documentation basics.
documentation_interface_justification: README.md explains the interface that is used
repo_public_justification: Repository on GitHub, which provides public git repositories with URLs.
repo_track_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git can track the changes, who made them, and when they were made.
repo_distributed_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git is distributed.
version_unique_justification: The primary single user uses git commit records to identify releases.
version_tags_justification: Full releases are tagged using 'git tag'.
release_notes_justification: CHANGELOG file is in top directory, see: https://github.com/QNimbus/LDAPImporter/blob/master/CHANGELOG.md
static_analysis_justification: A static code analysis tool examines the software code (as source code, intermediate code, or executable) without executing it with specific inputs. For purposes of this criterion, compiler warnings and "safe" language modes do not count as static code analysis tools (these typically avoid deep analysis because speed is vital). Examples of such static code analysis tools include cppcheck, clang static analyzer, FindBugs (including FindSecurityBugs), PMD, Brakeman, Coverity Quality Analyzer, and HP Enterprise Fortify Static Code Analyzer. Larger lists of tools can be found in places such as the Wikipedia list of tools for static code analysis, OWASP information on static code analysis, NIST list of source code security analyzers, and Wheeler's list of static analysis tools. The SWAMP is a no-cost platform for assessing vulnerabilities in software using a variety of tools. If there are no FLOSS static analysis tools available for the implementation language(s) used, select 'N/A'.
discussion_justification: GitHub supports discussions on issues and pull requests.
hardened_site_justification: Found all required security hardening headers.
